Conversation:
Patient: I've been experiencing sharp, intermittent pain around my left eye for the past two days. It's becoming quite bothersome.

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear you're experiencing pain around your left eye. Did you injure your eye in any way?

Patient: No, I don't think I injured it or anything like that, at least not that I can remember.

TriageMD: I understand. Just to confirm, you don't recall any injury to your eye, correct?

Patient: No, I don't recall any injury to my eye. The pain just started out of nowhere, and it's been coming and going for the past couple of days. It's really sharp and mainly around my left eye, which makes it hard to focus on anything else when it happens.

TriageMD: I understand that the pain is quite bothersome. Just to clarify, you haven't experienced any injury to your eye, correct?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Iâ€™m sorry to hear youâ€™re in pain. Can you tell me if your vision is blurred or if light hurts your eyes?

Patient: No, my vision isn't blurred, and light doesn't seem to bother my eyes either. The pain is sharp and just around my left eye, but my vision seems fine otherwise. It's more of a discomfort that makes it hard to concentrate when it happens.

TriageMD: I understand how uncomfortable that must be. Is your eyeball or eyelid red?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Does the pain seem to come from behind your eye?

Patient: Yes.

TriageMD: Thank you for the information. Do you have two or more of the following symptoms: a severe headache, sensitivity to bright light, pain when you bend your head forward, or feelings of drowsiness or confusion?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Is there an area of tenderness in your temple above the affected eye?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Is there an area of tenderness over your nose or in your cheekbones?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Given your symptoms, it's important to consult with your doctor for a proper evaluation. They can help determine the cause of your pain and recommend appropriate treatment. Take care.

Conversation:
Patient: I've been experiencing some blurring in my vision and occasionally see floating spots. Should I be worried about this?

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing these symptoms. Did you injure your head recently?

Patient: I don't think I've had any recent head injuries, but it's hard to say for sure. I can't remember anything specific happening.

TriageMD: It's understandable to be uncertain. Just to clarify, have you experienced any head injuries, even minor ones, recently?

Patient: No, I don't think I've had any head injuries recently, at least nothing that I can remember.

TriageMD: I understand. Just to confirm, are you certain you haven't had any head injuries recently, even minor ones?

Patient: No, I'm pretty certain I haven't had any head injuries recently. I haven't hit my head or had any accidents that I can recall. The blurring and floaters just started happening, and I can't think of anything that might have caused them.

TriageMD: I understand your concern. Have you suddenly lost some or all of the field of vision in one or both eyes?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: I understand that you're experiencing blurring in your vision. It's important to take these symptoms seriously. I recommend that you seek medical attention as soon as possible to get a proper evaluation.

Patient: Yes.

TriageMD: Is only one eye affected, or are both eyes experiencing the blurring and floaters?

Patient: Yes.

TriageMD: Do you feel any pain in the affected eye?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: It's important that you see a doctor immediately. Your symptoms could indicate a detached retina, which requires prompt attention. Please seek medical help as soon as possible.

Conversation:
Patient: My daughter has been complaining of pain in her right ear since last night. Could this be an ear infection?

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that your daughter is in pain. To help assess her condition, does the pain get worse when you pull down on her earlobe?

Patient: Yes, she did say it hurts more when I tried pulling down on her earlobe, but I'm not entirely sure if that's the main issue.

TriageMD: I understand your concern. Just to clarify, does the pain indeed get worse when you pull down on her earlobe? This can help indicate if it might be related to the ear itself.

Patient: Yes, it does seem to hurt more when I pull down on her earlobe. She winces and says it feels more painful. She's also been a bit fussy and has had trouble sleeping, which makes me think it might be an ear infection.

TriageMD: It sounds like she may be experiencing an ear infection, especially since the pain worsens when you pull down on her earlobe. It's also common for children to be fussy and have trouble sleeping when they're in pain. It would be a good idea to consult a healthcare professional for a proper evaluation and treatment.

Patient: Yes, I think so. It seems like it could be an ear infection, but I'm not entirely sure.

TriageMD: I understand your uncertainty. Just to confirm, does the pain indeed get worse when you pull down on her earlobe? This can help indicate if it might be related to an ear infection.

Patient: Yes, the pain does seem to get worse when I pull down on her earlobe. She winces and says it hurts more. Along with the ear pain, she's been quite fussy and hasn't been sleeping well, which makes me suspect it could be an ear infection. I'm planning to call her doctor to get it checked out.

TriageMD: It sounds like you're doing the right thing by planning to call her doctor. Just to confirm, does the pain indeed get worse when you pull down on her earlobe? This can help indicate if it might be related to an ear infection.

Patient: I'm not entirely sure, but it does seem like the pain might get worse when I pull down on her earlobe. She's been pretty uncomfortable and fussy, so it's hard to tell exactly what's going on. I think it's best to have her checked by a doctor to be sure.

TriageMD: I understand that it can be difficult to assess her pain. Just to clarify, does the pain get worse when you pull down on her earlobe? This can help determine if it might be related to an ear infection.

Patient: Yes.

TriageMD: It sounds like your daughter may have an infection of the ear canal, especially since the pain worsens when you pull on her earlobe. I recommend seeing her doctor for a proper evaluation and treatment. I hope she feels better soon.

Conversation:
Patient: I've been experiencing a constant ringing in my ears for the past week, and it's becoming quite bothersome. What should I do?

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing this. Do you have any hearing loss along with the ringing in your ears?

Patient: No, I haven't noticed any hearing loss. It's just the ringing that's been constant. It started about a week ago, and it's more noticeable when I'm in a quiet room or trying to sleep. It's really starting to affect my concentration and sleep quality.

TriageMD: I understand how bothersome that can be. Did you begin hearing the ringing during or after an airplane flight?

Patient: No, it didn't start after a flight. It just began out of the blue about a week ago. I haven't been on a plane or anything like that recently.

TriageMD: I understand how concerning this can be. Have you taken or are you currently taking any prescription or over-the-counter medications?

Patient: I'm not really sure if any medications I'm taking might be causing it. I do take some over-the-counter stuff occasionally, but I haven't connected it to the ringing.

TriageMD: I understand. Just to clarify, are you currently taking or have you recently taken any prescription or over-the-counter medications that you might not have considered?

Patient: Yes, I think so. I take some over-the-counter stuff for allergies sometimes, and maybe some pain relievers here and there, but I haven't really thought about whether they could be related to the ringing.

TriageMD: It's good to know what you're taking. Just to confirm, are you currently taking or have you recently taken any prescription or over-the-counter medications that might be relevant?

Patient: Yes.

TriageMD: It's important to talk to your doctor about the ringing in your ears. Some over-the-counter medications, including certain allergy medications and pain relievers like aspirin, can cause tinnitus as a side effect. Your doctor can help determine the cause and suggest appropriate steps to manage it.

Conversation:
Patient: I've been having trouble hearing conversations clearly, especially when there's background noise. Can you help me understand what's going on?

TriageMD: I understand that having trouble hearing conversations, especially with background noise, can be frustrating. Do you have an earache?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: I understand your concern. Does your ear have a sticky yellow discharge?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Have you had a cold or a sore throat in the past week?

Patient: No, I haven't really had a cold or sore throat recently, at least not that I've noticed.

TriageMD: I understand. Just to confirm, have you had any symptoms like a cold or sore throat in the past week?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Can you hear low-pitched sounds, like a knock on the door, better than high-pitched sounds, like a doorbell?

Patient: Not really, I think I hear both about the same, but it's hard to say for sure.

TriageMD: I understand. Just to clarify, can you hear low-pitched sounds, like a knock on the door, better than high-pitched sounds, like a doorbell?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Thank you for your responses. Are you currently taking or have you recently taken any nonprescription or prescription medications?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Do you experience occasional episodes of dizziness that make the room seem to spin?

Patient: Not really, but I do enjoy a good spin class at the gym!

TriageMD: I appreciate your response! Just to clarify, do you have occasional episodes of dizziness that make the room seem to spin?

Patient: I can't say for sure. I haven't noticed anything like that, but sometimes it's hard to tell if it's just being tired or something else.

TriageMD: I understand that it can be hard to distinguish. Just to confirm, do you have occasional episodes of dizziness that make the room seem to spin?

Patient: No, I haven't experienced any episodes where the room seems to spin. I sometimes feel a bit off when I'm tired, but nothing that feels like true dizziness or vertigo.

TriageMD: Thank you for sharing that. Are you over 60 years old?

Patient: No, I'm not over 60. I'm still a bit away from that milestone!

TriageMD: Has your hearing worsened over a period of several weeks or longer?

Patient: Yes, I think my hearing has gradually worsened over the past few months. It wasn't very noticeable at first, but now I find myself asking people to repeat themselves more often, especially in noisy environments. It's been a slow change, but it's definitely become more of an issue recently.

TriageMD: Thank you for sharing that. Have other members of your family experienced a gradual loss of hearing as well?

Patient: Well, my family does love to gather for big dinners, and we often end up talking over each other. It can get pretty loud, but it's always a good time!

TriageMD: Iâ€™m glad to hear you enjoy those family gatherings! Just to clarify, have other members of your family experienced a gradual loss of hearing as well?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: It sounds like you may be experiencing hearing loss that could be related to an earwax blockage. I recommend seeing your doctor for a proper evaluation and treatment. They can help determine the cause and provide the appropriate care.

Conversation:
Patient: I've been experiencing a sore throat for a few days now, and it's really uncomfortable when I swallow. What should I do?

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing discomfort. To help assess your situation, could you please let me know if your temperature is 100Â°F or higher?

Patient: Yes, I've been running a fever. My temperature has been hovering around 101Â°F. I've also been feeling quite fatigued and have noticed some swelling in my throat.

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're feeling this way. Do you have two or more of the following symptoms: headache, cough, or aching joints or bones?

Patient: Well, I have had a bit of a headache off and on, but I wouldn't say it's constant. As for coughing or aching joints, not really. It's mostly just the sore throat and the fever that's bothering me.

TriageMD: Thank you for sharing that. Just to clarify, do you have two or more of the following symptoms: headache, cough, or aching joints or bones? It sounds like your sore throat and fever are quite concerning.

Patient: No.

TriageMD: I understand how uncomfortable this must be for you. Do you have any swelling or tenderness in your neck?

Patient: Yes.

TriageMD: Is the swollen or tender area in front of your ear or at the angle of your jaw?

Patient: Yes, I've noticed that the swelling and tenderness are mostly around the angle of my jaw. It's quite noticeable and feels a bit uncomfortable when I touch it or when I'm trying to swallow.

TriageMD: It sounds like you may have mumps, especially with the swelling around your jaw and the other symptoms you've described. I recommend that you see your doctor as soon as possible for a proper evaluation and treatment. Take care.

Flowchart: Hoarseness Or Loss Of Voice Flowchart
Conversation:
Patient: I've been experiencing a persistent hoarseness in my voice for the past few weeks. Should I be concerned?

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing hoarseness. Did the hoarseness begin within the past 3 days?

Patient: No, it started a few weeks ago and hasn't gone away. It's been pretty persistent, and I'm starting to get a bit worried since it hasn't improved.

TriageMD: I understand your concern about persistent hoarseness. Does your job require you to talk a lot, such as being a teacher or a lawyer?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Have you been drinking a lot of alcohol?

Patient: No, I haven't been drinking much alcohol at all. I usually only have an occasional drink on the weekends, but nothing excessive.

TriageMD: Do you smoke, or have you been in a smoky place, like a bar?

Patient: No, I don't smoke, and I haven't been in any smoky environments like bars or clubs recently. I've been quite mindful of avoiding smoke exposure.

TriageMD: It's good to hear that you're avoiding smoke exposure. To better understand your situation, do you have two or more of the following symptoms: sensitivity to cold weather, dry skin or dry hair, unexplained weight gain, or unexplained fatigue?

Patient: Yes, I've actually been experiencing quite a bit of fatigue lately, and my skin has been drier than usual. I also seem to be more sensitive to the cold than I used to be. I didn't really connect these symptoms to my hoarseness before, but now that you mention it, they have been bothering me as well.

TriageMD: Given your persistent hoarseness along with the fatigue, dry skin, and increased sensitivity to cold, it's important to see your doctor. These symptoms could indicate an underactive thyroid gland. Please make an appointment to discuss your concerns.

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear you're in pain. Do you feel the pain only when eating, or does it occur just after eating as well?

Patient: I'm not really sure. I think it might be worse when I'm eating, but it seems to linger for a bit after too. It's hard to tell exactly.

TriageMD: I understand it can be difficult to pinpoint. Just to clarify, do you feel the pain primarily while eating, or does it also occur just after eating?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Do you experience repeated episodes of throbbing pain in the tooth?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Is the pain in your tooth continuous, or do you have a temperature of 100Â°F or higher?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: It sounds like you're experiencing significant discomfort. I recommend seeing your dentist to get a proper evaluation and treatment. They can help determine the cause of your pain and provide the necessary care.

Conversation:
Patient: I've been having a lot of trouble swallowing lately, and it's starting to really worry me. Can I get some advice?

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're having trouble swallowing. Do you have a sore throat as well?

Patient: Not really, but I did try a new recipe for dinner last night. It was a bit spicier than I'm used to, so maybe that's related somehow.

TriageMD: It's possible that the spiciness could be causing some irritation. Do you have a sore throat or any other symptoms, like pain or discomfort when swallowing?

Patient: No, I don't have a sore throat or any pain when swallowing. It's more like a sensation of something being stuck or tightness in my throat. It's been happening more frequently since last night, but there's no actual pain.

TriageMD: I understand how concerning that can be. Does food seem to stick high up in your chest after you swallow it?

Patient: No, it doesn't feel like food is sticking in my chest after I swallow. It's more of a sensation in my throat, like there's a tightness or something is there, but it doesn't seem to be affecting how food goes down. It's just more noticeable when I'm not eating.

TriageMD: It sounds like you might be experiencing a sensation of a lump in your throat, which can happen even if you're swallowing normally. This can be related to various factors, including stress or irritation. If it continues or worsens, it would be a good idea to consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation.

Patient: I guess it could be stress or irritation, but I'm not really sure. It's just been bothering me since last night, and I'm not sure if it's something I should be worried about or if it'll just go away on its own.

TriageMD: It sounds like you can swallow normally, but you're experiencing a sensation of a lump in your throat. This can be uncomfortable, but if you're not having trouble with food going down, it may not be an emergency. However, if it persists or worsens, it's best to consult a healthcare professional for further evaluation.

Patient: Yeah, I totally get what you're saying. By the way, have you ever tried that new coffee shop downtown? Their lattes are amazing!

TriageMD: Just to clarify, do you swallow normally but feel a lump in your throat, or do you feel like food is not going down? Understanding this can help determine the next steps.

Patient: Yes.

TriageMD: It sounds like your swallowing issue could be related to anxiety or possibly gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). I recommend seeing your doctor for a proper evaluation and to discuss your symptoms further. They can help determine the cause and suggest appropriate treatment. Take care!

Conversation:
Patient: I've been experiencing soreness on my tongue and inside my mouth for a few days. It's getting uncomfortable. What should I do?

TriageMD: I'm sorry to hear that you're experiencing soreness on your tongue and inside your mouth. Is your tongue sore?

Patient: I'm not really sure, it just feels uncomfortable overall. It's hard to tell if it's just the tongue or more than that.

TriageMD: I understand that it can be hard to pinpoint the discomfort. Can you tell me if your tongue feels sore specifically, or is it more of a general discomfort in your mouth?

Patient: Yes.

TriageMD: Is the soreness limited to one area of your tongue, or is it more widespread?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Is your tongue red and painful all over?

Patient: No, my tongue isn't red and painful all over. It's more of a general discomfort in my mouth, but I can't see any specific redness or swelling. It just feels uncomfortable and a bit sensitive, especially when I eat certain foods.

TriageMD: Do you have any discolored areas inside your mouth or on your tongue?

Patient: I'm not really sure. I haven't noticed any obvious discoloration, but I might have missed something. It's hard to tell just by looking.

TriageMD: I understand that it can be difficult to assess. If you haven't noticed any discoloration, that's a good sign, but it's still important to monitor any changes. Have you experienced any other symptoms, like a fever, swelling, or difficulty swallowing?

Patient: No, I haven't experienced any fever, swelling, or difficulty swallowing. It's mainly just the soreness and sensitivity in my mouth. I haven't noticed any other symptoms that stand out.

TriageMD: It sounds uncomfortable, and I understand your concern. Just to confirm, have you noticed any discolored areas inside your mouth or on your tongue?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Are your gums painful, red, and swollen?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Do you have any sores on or around your lips?

Patient: No, I don't have any sores on or around my lips. Everything looks normal on the outside; it's just the inside of my mouth that's been feeling sore and sensitive.

TriageMD: It sounds like you're experiencing discomfort without any obvious signs of infection or sores, which is good. However, since the soreness has persisted for a few days and is affecting your comfort, I recommend seeing your doctor for a proper evaluation. They can help determine the cause and suggest appropriate treatment. Take care!

TriageMD: It sounds like you generally maintain good oral hygiene. Just to confirm, do you ever brush and floss less often than twice a day?

Patient: Well, I do love a good cup of coffee in the morning. It's just the perfect way to start the day!

TriageMD: I understand that coffee is a favorite for many! Just to clarify, do you brush and floss your teeth less often than twice a day?

Patient: No, I generally brush and floss at least twice a day. I might miss a flossing session occasionally, but I make sure to brush my teeth every morning and night.

TriageMD: Just to confirm, do you brush and floss your teeth less often than twice a day?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Do you wear dentures?

Patient: No.

TriageMD: Have you had garlic, onions, or other strong-smelling foods, or alcohol within the past 24 hours?

Patient: No, I haven't had any garlic, onions, or strong-smelling foods recently, and I haven't consumed alcohol in the past 24 hours. I try to avoid those when I'm going out or meeting people, just to be on the safe side.

TriageMD: Do you smoke?

Patient: Yes, I do smoke. I've been smoking for a few years now. I know it can contribute to bad breath, and I'm trying to cut down, but it's been challenging. I try to use mints or gum to help with the smell, but it seems like it's not enough sometimes.

TriageMD: Smoking can indeed contribute to bad breath, as it affects oral health and can lead to inflammation. This inflammation may increase the risk of nasal and sinus infections, which can also contribute to persistent bad breath. It's great that you're trying to cut down, as reducing smoking can help improve your breath over time. If you're concerned, consider discussing this with your healthcare provider for more tailored advice.
